abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Employment Development
            Policy Loan Project for Tunisia were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: the Bank should not expect too
            much from consultations with stakeholders in a country
            tightly controlled by the security apparatus. In the
            interviews carried out for the preparation of the completion
            report, most interlocutors complained that there had been
            too little consultation in the development of the reform
            program. In a society undermined by deep corruption and
            cronyism, statements from the ruling elite should not be
            taken at face value. In his electoral program for 2009-2014,
            President Ben Ali made employment a national priority. He
            promised reforms to address the unemployment and social
            protection challenges. While he made his speeches, he was
            strengthening the rent seeking system which was stifling
            entrepreneurship and job creation. The previous regime,
            which seemed to be well entrenched, was swept away in a
            short period of time. Solid political economy analyses are
            essential to better understand the constraints and
            frustrations in a country where opportunities are scant
            because of deeply embedded corruption.
